column4: I have been serving my own private repository to conserve bandwidth but since installing jaunty apt complains about a missing Release.gpg file. What is this about?
and im still struggling to get apt to update from my local ftp repository
did you import the key file?
i followed a tutorial on creating a gpg key, importing the key in apt and then signing the Release file. But no joy.
the tutorial made it seem as if there was nothing overly involved about getting a secure apt setup
is there not a way to disable apt from checking for gpg signed release file?
what tutorial?
http://wiki.debian.org/SecureApt
what does it say when you try to install now?
W: Failed to fetch ftp://localhost/linux/ubuntu/dists/jaunty/Release  Unable to find expected entry  main/binary-i386/Packages in Meta-index file (malformed Release file?)
i have created the top-level Release file and signed it with a gpg key which I have imported to apt and that is the message it returns
did you try file instead of ftp?
i have not. I am trying to get ftp to work as this machine will serve to another on my network
have you verified you can ftp to that location?
indeed, and files have correct premissions and are downloadable
what does your source line look like?
deb ftp://localhost/linux/ubuntu jaunty main multiverse restricted universe
i have been serving a local repository since fiesty. my apt has only been insisting on a Release.gpg file since i installed jaunty yesterday. Can the apt security check not be turned off?
i have followed the guide you gave, but the error regarding the missing Release.gpg file persists.
it works like a charm with a file repo but that has its limitations for my purposes
is there a way to configure apt's behaviour for network based updates?
